summary: In the late 1960s and 1970s, fear grips the city of San Francisco as a serial killer called Zodiac stalks its residents. Investigators (Mark Ruffalo, Anthony Edwards) and reporters (Jake Gyllenhaal, Robert Downey Jr.) become obsessed with learning the killer's identity and bringing him to justice. Set in the San Francisco area over, primarily, a ten-year period in the 1970s, David Fincher's Zodiac documents the investigation into the ruthless serial killer who taunted both the police and the media while conducting his horrific murder spree.  Showing the chain of events from the perspectives of police investigator Dave Toschi (Mark Ruffalo) and San Francisco Chronicle cartoonist Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), Zodiac is a gripping and gritty thriller that somehow manages to hold the interest of the viewer for the entirety of its considerable 160-minute running time, an intense character study of those in pursuit of the killer. "Zodiac" follows the police and journalists investigation into the real life murderer known as  The Zodiac. Director David Fincher uses the books of newspaper cartoonist turned investigator Robert Greysmith ( Jake Gillenhaal )to tell the tale of one of America's most infamous serial killers.

What makes the Zodiac such a mysterious character is how he used coded messages sent to newspapers to give clues to not only his identity but also confirming his actions and activities. Since the first confirmed Zodiac killing in 1968,  despite many coded letters and a number of suspects, no arrest was ever made and still today the identity of The Zodiac remains a mystery. 

The film follows the police investigation by Dave Toschi ( Mark Ruffalo ) and Bill Armstrong ( Anthony Edwards ) with assistance from journalist Paul Avery ( Robert Downey Jr. ) and cartoonist Robert Greysmith. Fincher's focus is on the main characters as they Persue the killer,  digging  deeper into the mystery and hitting brick walls. John Carroll Lynch gives a genuinely chilling performance as Arthur Leigh Allen, who at one point becomes a prime suspect in the investigation.

Finchers attention to period detail and recreation of the initial killings along with the focus on the main characters makes for a quiet , slow paced, unsettling movie experience. There is really no conclusion however, as the legacy of the horror continues to present day. The Zodiac vanished and was never brought to Justice. This was despite so much evidence, coded confessions and a thorough investigation spanning many years. What is clear from the film is the disappointment and frustration experienced by of all the main characters who never got to experience the identity of The Zodiac killer being revealed.

Today I watched "Zodiac," I believe for the, no joke, 7th or 8th time. The movie covers the dense timeline of the "Zodiac Killer's" many crimes and the police investigation that followed, in an attempt to identify and eventually prosecute him. The main character of the movie is Robert Graysmith, played by Jake Gyllenhall, a cartoonist for the San Francisco Chronicle, who became engaged with the investigation due to the Zodiac Killer's contacting of several San Francisco-based newspapers. For a while, investigators thought that the Zodiac would be found, and they identified some promising suspects. However, the trail eventually ran cold, due to the (presumed) end of the Zodiac's spree and bureaucratic roadblocks among the police and the government, and it seemed that everybody had just moved on. Graysmith, however, did not, and was willing to put his familial relationships and his career on the line in order to write and publish a book about the Zodiac. What I enjoy most about this movie is that while its creators were tasked with the challenge of having to cover a vast number of years and a multitude of information within a traditional ~2.5-hour span, it felt to me that not a single detail went overlooked, and not a single (important) event was left out. Additionally, I felt that the movie's creators and actors did a fantastic job of capturing the essence of life in America, specifically San Francisco, in the 1960s-70s, from the set and costume design and the hair and makeup, to how the actors interacted with their environment and each other. I feel transported back in time every time I watch this movie. I'm also incredibly impressed with the range of emotions each of the actors is able to convey within the movie, especially since I've seen several of the cast members in less "serious" roles, so their performance in "Zodiac" is beyond impressive to me. These characteristics contribute to the unmatched "rewatchability" this movie holds. If you are in the mood to watch a movie, I would absolutely recommend that you go watch "Zodiac."

Zodiac is an incredibly thrilling experience from start to finish. The film does a lot of things very well, with flaws few and far between. First off, this film has a star studded cast with the likes of Mark Ruffalo, Robert Downey Jr, and Jake Gyllenhall, with Jake giving what may be his best lead performance in a film ever. The movie is mainly dialogue, with a few murder scenes by the zodiac killer thrown in the mix. These scenes are not bad by any means, but they're pretty basic and dull, and some of them even get cut off before you see what happens. The other major flaw to this movie in my opinion is the handling of Downey Jr's character. I really liked where they were going with the character in the first couple acts of the film. However, the character gets a little bit left behind and we do not get to see much of an end to his character arc, some people might be okay with it but it wasn't quite enough for me. Besides those two flaws the film does not have any other flaws that stick out enough to affect the score I'm giving this film. This film does a great job at keeping you on the edge of your seat, waiting to see what might happen next, or who the new suspect will be. The thing that surprised me the most about the movie was how suspenseful it could be, as I could feel the stress building up in me, fearing for what could happen next. The greatest strength this film possesses is its ability to keep you entertained for so long with so much dialogue. It never gets stale at all through the course of the movie, and that's a rare occurrence in modern films, as I find a very large amount of movies like to rely on flashy action and comedy to keep viewers entertained. The characters also work so well together and bounce off of each others' performances, to really bring this amazing film to life. Overall, this movie is definitely a right time, right place kind of film, that you won't be watching on a regular basis unless you're a hardcore fan of the crime genre. This is a great film to put on during a movie date with someone special, or even a movie night with your friends or family, but is definitely best watched as a solo flick so you can really get a grip on the story. Easy 4/5, and would've been a 5 with more care towards RDJ's character.

But Graysmith is at least presented seriously in this deeply grave plot, while other characters, like Robert Downey jr's reporter, who appears like he's some kind of parody act, obviously overacting, as if this is to underline the lack of focus and cooperation within investigators and media. But does that really work? The same also goes for some of the police characters, except from Mark Ruffalo portaying Inspector David Toschi. Together with Chloë Sevigny he probably does the best acting performance, keeping the tension at a certain level. It's sometimes hard to find a good balance and true intention in David Fincher's direction, and it's likely a logic to ending up with a series of questions due to the nature of the plot, which actually lacks a conclusion. But as a drama, it might feel like having been gazing into a dark void that only has been growing more empty. It's perhaps a great point with it, but that's all there is.

Focuses too much on Graysmith, a Sherlock wannabe who injected himself into the case and has come under suspicion for possibly fabricating details in order to sell his books, such as the insinuation that the Zodiac harassed him on the phone several times. He might've got some hangups, but that doesn't sound like Zodiac's style to me; I doubt Zodiac even knew he existed until Graysmith wrote his first book on the case years later. And Graysmith has been pointing his finger at Arthur Leigh Allen since the start, only to end up being embarrassed when DNA tests did not match Allen. Not really the guy you want to focus on in this case.

The film tries to recreate the 60's & 70's, but the dialogue doesn't ring true in that respect; the chosen profanity and certain phrases are irritatingly from the new millennium. Annoying little details are thrown in, such as Toschi's obsession with animal crackers, that add nothing to the film. The details of who each person is is not of particular importance in this story; we should only care who the Zodiac and his victims are. History has shown that Dave Toschi, for example, did a lousy job on this case, so detailing his little eccentricities is irrelevant and uninteresting because he was a failure. Some of it is most likely not even accurate, such as his idly watching Belli and later a boardroom of newspaper editors carelessly handle blood-stained pieces of cloth without immediately intervening to protect the evidence. The police techniques and their dialogue feel phony and contrived. The acting is only so-so; competent but somewhat wooden. These people seem like actors acting, rather than involving us in the drama and mystery of the story. Downey Jr. seems to simply be playing himself, for the most part.

Also the story is told out of sequence, which Fincher seems to think is artful license but comes across as pretentious and confusing for those only moderately familiar with the Zodiac story. Fincher does get credit for revealing the Kathleen Johns story as a probably hoax - but why even take the time to show that scene then, when it could just be alluded to? The movie is too long as is and needed trimming. Graysmith on a date? Come on. How does that have *anything* to do with this legendary case?

"All in all, Zodiac gains the most generous praise that a film based on a true story can ever receive from me. James Vanderbilt's screenplay convinced me to research everything about the real events as soon as the movie finished, which is undeniably an impactful effect of watching such a well-written, captivating narrative with well-developed, authentic characters. Zodiac is quite simply the most meticulous, engrossing, and well made police procedural film ever!

Okay, that's a bold statement considering the many outstanding police procedural films made over the years. But at least in the last twenty years, I do feel that Zodiac (2007) is the best. Masterfully directed by David Fincher, the film is ultimately about obsession for the truth and how we as viewers see and relate to truth through various mediums including film.

Based on the book of the same title by Robert Graysmith, Zodiac tells the true story of the manhunt for the Zodiac Killer, a serial murderer who terrorized the San Francisco Bay Area during the late 1960s and early 1970s, taunting police with letters, bloodstained clothing, and ciphers mailed to newspapers. The case remains one of the United States' most infamous unsolved crimes. (Wikipedia)

The story opens with the murders interwoven with scenes of the editorial staff of the San Francisco Chronicle dealing with the received cryptic Zodiac letters. Here we are introduced to lead political cartoonist Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), and crime reporter Paul Avery (Robert Downey Jr.). Following the murder of San Francisco taxicab driver Paul Stine, we are introduced to police inspectors Dave Toschi (Mark Ruffalo) and his partner Bill Armstrong (Anthony Edwards). This mid-section of the film forms the bulk of the police investigation but ultimately leads nowhere as Toschi is not able to find hard physical evidence to incriminate the prime suspect. The final third of the film follows Graysmith as he obsessively tries to tie the circumstantial evidence from three different counties together to find the killer. With all of the main characters, the obsession to find the truth behind the Zodiac's true identity wreaks havoc on their personal and professional lives. What's most fascinating about this film is how director David Fincher is able to pull audiences out of themselves to reveal that we as the public and movie viewers do the same thing, obsessively seeking the truth. All mediums during that time period are explored as we listen to radio callers and view television news broadcasts regarding the Zodiac killer. We also see a barrage of thousands of informants as they all give their interpretation of the truth. Of course it is one of these informants that ultimately leads to the prime suspect, but how we deal with all this information and sift through it, is one of the most mind blowing elements of this film. Perhaps most interesting is how the film is a commentary on how we as audiences view films like this. We too are drawn into the obsession and are frustrated by how we are forced to ignore the obvious "circumstantial evidence" due to a lack of physical evidence. Like the real life characters, we are also swayed by our own bias perspective and fears, sometimes forcing the truth because of our desire for completion and resolution. However, the only satisfaction we are able to find is the same satisfaction Graysmith achieves by his 99% identification of the Zodiac's identity. We are reminded that just like in real life, the crimes sometimes go unsolved.

On a technical level, there is so much to admire about Zodiac like it's brilliant construction, precise historically accurate production design, subdued realistic acting, beautiful cinematography and framing, and dynamic ever changing soundtrack. This is the first mature work of David Fincher and perhaps his masterpiece. There are two things that I specifically appreciate about Zodiac; the pacing of the film and David Fincher's restrained directing.

The film's deliberate consistent pacing is brilliantly appropriate here. Some critics have described the pacing as "slow" and lacking in action. The pacing, rather, is intense and unrelentingly suspenseful. It also is never static. The pace of the film slowly builds in momentum especially in the last hour keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The pacing also aids in the film's more creepy moments. Cars stalking victims in the middle of the night. Investigators coming uncomfortably close to suspects. All this is made even more frightening when you contemplate that these crimes and events really happened. I also find the atmosphere and pacing in this film to be far more unnerving than any slasher film. 

The second thing that stands out for me is David Fincher's unusually restrained directing. Fincher, known for his over the top graphic violence in many of his other films like Seven (1995) and Fight Club (1999), is quite restrained in Zodiac. This doesn't mean there aren't any violent sequences. The few murders that are depicted are quite shocking and brutal, but none of it is gratuitous or glorifying. In fact, the violence, while brutal, are depicted exactly as it was described by survivors of the Zodiac killer. Fincher has stated that he did not want to inspire the next serial killer in any way. Rather the violence serves in building the tension and adds urgency to the story. That being said, Zodiac has far less violence than any other Fincher thriller. It's far less distracting too. Through the restraint, we can focus on Fincher's remarkable skills as a director, as he sweeps us into this enthralling story and authentic time period.

For all of these reasons, Zodiac is my favorite police procedural and in my top two David Fincher films.

Most fictional mysteries conclude with the perpetrators being expose and their motives revealed. Zodiac revolves around a mystery which has never been conclusively solved – the identity of the Zodiac killer, who terrorized California in the late 60's and early 70's. Zodiac suggests a solution to this enigma, but also leaves room for the viewer to reject the film's interpretation. This ambiguity is a sign of respect for the audience's intelligence. None of the suspects were ever conclusively proven to have been Zodiac, so I appreciate not having the director's pet theory being depicted as fact. The film achieves this ambiguity not only through the content of its script, but also by having three different actors portray Zodiac in his onscreen appearances, none of whom play any of the suspects.

Obsession is the main theme in Zodiac. Several characters destroy their lives by focusing on the case to the exclusion of everything else. The effects of the case on the investigators are as much the focus of the film as Zodiac himself. Focusing more on heady themes and less on the brutal murders (reenactments of Zodiac's crimes make up only a small portion of the runtime) is admirable but requires a higher level of skill on the part of the writers and actors. While Zodiac isn't as brilliantly written as The Silence of the Lambs, the writer, actors, and director display a high level of skill in their skillful depiction of the ruined relationships and lost opportunities which accompany the characters' obsession with catching the killer.

Zodiac also beautifully captures California during this time period, with its period-correct San Francisco skyline, absent the Transamerica Pyramid, which is constructed in a time lapse midway through the film as a clever method to depict the passage of time. Such relics as a police telephone box and Atari's Pong also make an appearance. Perhaps most interestingly for me, given my interest in commercial aviation, were the accurate airline liveries which appear in the film, with several of the main characters flying on a plane operated by the defunct carrier PSA midway through the film. For me, the movie was almost worth watching simply for its glimpse into the time period. Fortunately, the film is not solely interesting as a period piece – Zodiac is also an intriguing murder mystery with an engrossing depiction of obsession.

Zodiac is crime/drama film directed by David Fincher, and it was released all the way back in 2007. A decade ago! Dang, that is hard to believe. Anyway, I wasn't able to see Zodiac when it initially released in theaters and really I had never even thought about it until I saw it got added to Netflix this month. I immediately added it to my list and finally got around to watching it. Zodiac may not be as good as Se7en, and it's definitely not the best crime/drama movie ever made, but it's still pretty damn good.

Plot

As you might have guessed based off of the title, Zodiac, the movie is all about the Zodiac killer, and the people who try to figure out the identity of the killer. I won't go too deep into spoilers, but if you were alive when the Zodiac killer was actually active or if you have read the book, you'll know at least some of the story. Essentially, there's a serial killer on the loose in California and he likes to taunt the press/police after he successfully commits a murder. The movie follows the detectives, a journalist, and a cartoonist as they try to figure out who the killer is. I wasn't alive during that time, and I never read the book or do any research on the subject. So this was a whole new story to me, and I feel like I benefited because of that. The entire time I was trying to figure out who the killer actually was. The director does try to throw a few curveballs at the audience, but I feel like they were almost unnecessary and actually hindered my final assessment of the film. Not that throwing curve balls at the audience is necessarily a bad thing, but the twists just weren't executed all that well.

Anyway, the story kept me enthralled from start to finish. I was completely invested in the investigation by about the half-way point. I didn't look at how much longer was left in the movie once, and I even put off going to the bathroom because I did not want to pause the movie. That's how into it I was. One challenge that Fincher really overcame was the timeline. This movie spans a lot of years. And sometimes that can harm a film dearly. Jumping weeks, months, years at a time can sometimes kill a film's momentum, and lose the audience in the process. But this movie doesn't do that. It can jump weeks or months and you'll hardly even notice. It never loses momentum and it never becomes a drag.

Overall, the story of Zodiac is incredibly gripping and well done. Fincher does a great job of making a "cold case" into a movie that actually has a resolution that is satisfying, and he is able to make even the boring stuff seem interesting.

Characters

Almost all of the characters in Zodiac are great. They're engaging, unique, and have great arcs. But Paul Avery, who is portrayed by Robert Downey Jr., is the weakest character of the entire film. I get that Fincher was a bit hogtied when it came to each character's arc, but man what a waste of Robert Downey Jr. His character has a pretty small role in the film in the grand scheme of things and doesn't actually add a whole lot to it. He drinks, he smokes, and he helps the case along a little but for the most part he's just there. And it gets to a point in the film where he's completely unnecessary, but they give him a few scenes anyway. I mean, Zodiac is a long film, so cutting out these excess scenes with his character would have trimmed at least a few minutes off of the 2 hour and 37 minute run time. But it is Robert Downey Jr. so I guess they didn't want to cut any of his scenes. Now, I want to make it perfectly clear that Paul Avery doesn't hinder the film or impact it in a negative way. He just doesn't add a whole lot to it and overall seems unnecessary. The rest of the characters are great, though.

Potential Audience

Zodiac is a mature film. The first half of the movie contains quite a few murder scenes, and I would say that no one under the age of 16 or 17 should watch it. Heck, some people well into their 40s may find some of the scenes in this movie disturbing. It all depends on how much ultra-realistic violence actually impacts you. If you like crime, drama, or thriller movies you'll definitely have a good time with Zodiac. Just don't let your young child watch it.

Conclusion

Zodiac is a great film. The story is a quite the ride and the characters keep you engaged. The film does run a bit long, but because the story is so fascinating I doubt you'll even notice how long it truly is. If you have Netflix, go watch it as soon as you can. If you don't have Netflix, go rent it for a couple of bucks-it's worth it.

The plot of the movie revolves around the investigation of the infamous Zodiac killer in the 1960s in the San Francisco area and how a cartoonist, Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), a homicide detective, David Toschi (Mark Ruffalo) and a news reporter, Paul Avery (Robert Downey Jr.), aim to crack his identity but see their personal lives greatly affected by their involvement in the case.

The main reason why I absolutely love this movie is because it is able to draw me in completely into its story. 'David Fincher' is one of my favorite directors and I really feel that this is one of his best-directed movies. 'David Fincher' and cinematographer 'Harris Savides', portray the 1960-1970 era terrifically. The costumes, the sets and era transport you straight to the 1960s-1970s and make the movie visually appealing. Moreover, 'Fincher' induces a suspenseful and tense atmosphere to almost every scene in the movie, especially the scenes when the 'Zodiac' killer is shown. This kept me intrigued throughout the whole movie and like the characters in the movie; I kept trying to crack the case myself. The thing that pleasantly surprised me the most, however, was, how well the humor in this movie was handled. The dialogues written by 'James Vanderbilt' were really funny and 'Fincher' used humor really well to keep me engaged in the portions of the movie when the characters are not doing much but talking. The interrogation scenes or the scenes in the 'Tribune' office become memorable because of this humor. 

The other thing this movie, surprisingly, nails really well is its handling of its characters and its pace. Since the movie has a wide array of characters and spans over a pretty big era, this movie could have really become messy and overlong, but it is so well edited by 'Angus Wall' that I really could not think of looking away for a moment. Each moment in the movie is engaging, whether it is the characters talking or any action-taking place. Also, 'Fincher' does an outstanding job of handling all his characters well, especially, his 3 main characters, all of who manage to make a lasting impression. None of the supporting characters come off as unnecessary (most of them are intriguing) and add a significant amount of detail to a story that is riveting to say the least. 

Finally, the acting in this movie is also all-round terrific. A massive amount of credit has to go to the writing of these characters but in the end, it is the actors who really bring these characters to life. The supporting cast does an extremely good job in the movie. Particularly, 'Brain Cox', 'Anthony Edwards' and 'John Carroll Lynch' make big impressions. 'Anthony Edwards' and 'Mark Ruffalo' share some truly funny moments and complement each other really well in the scenes of investigations. 'John Carroll Lynch' has a few scenes in the movie but really manages to impress with a complex performance. The major cast is similarly exceptionally impressive in this movie. 'Downey Jr.' is at his cocky best as 'Paul Avery' and though he does not have as much screen time as 'Gyllenhaal' and 'Ruffalo', he really shines in his scenes and shares some truly hilarious moments with 'Gyllenhaal's' character.  'Mark Ruffalo' is also terrific as 'David Toschi'. He gets some the best lines in the movie and he delivers them with aplomb and manages to also really impress in his more serious scenes. My favorite character in the movie, however, was 'Jake Gyllenhaal's' character because I felt I really saw the case like he did. I felt that 'Gyllenhaal's' character was extremely difficult to make convincing and 'Gyllenhaal' did terrifically to make this characters motives and incentives seem believable. He infuses his character with tremendous likeability and that makes it hard to not root for him in the movie. 

Overall, I see Zodiac, as a hidden masterpiece that stays with you long after it has finished and manages to constantly engage you with its tremendous characters and brilliant dialogue. A movie that manages to really define what a serial killer thriller should be like -- Zodiac is one of my all time favorite thrillers, probably just below my all time favorite thriller - Se7en.

David Fincher treads into the dark and heavy true crime world, where everyone's a suspect and obsession is everything. It's a more  suitable story for him than say Panic Room, with a lot more subtext going on and sets him onto the true path to greatness, in my opinion. Zodiac is based on a true stories set between the late 60's and early 90's. It follows the obsession of 3 men, who's paths intertwine as a serial killer, who calls himself the Zodiac, goes on a murderous rampage and enjoys publicity with his work by playing a game of cat and mouse with the media. To this day, the Zodiac has never been found guilty, however there were many a suspect and this film tries its best to touch on what it can, without coming outright and pointing the finger, even though it cant help itself from blurting it out from time to time. Paul Avery, a big shot news reporter, with quite the penchant for fame and booze teams up with a fellow team member and cartoonist, Robert Greysmith, once the letters come flying in thick and fast and the bodies start racking up. Both men fall into a downward spiral, hunting for a man that cannot be found, eventually David Toschi gets dragged into it as a detective, who looses a lot more than sleep over his decade long obsession with catching this man responsible. It's a long winded, thick and fast who done it, without the big reveal as such. The ensemble here is top notch, not one actor out of place, Jake Gyllenhaal is ace at the code breaking and book worm cartoonist, bouncing wildly off his counter part Robert Downey JR, who plays Avery, an alcoholic drug abuser who shoots for fame and just about loses everything. The chemistry between them is brilliant, if not a little short lived. Mark Ruffalo makes up the trio with Dave, this man is such an understated actor, Ruffalo has been at it for some time now and every role he touches, he smacks with professionalism and a naturalistic nature, very few actors to date can touch on. You can see the struggle in this mans eyes constantly, Ruffalo lives this character he doesnt act him. The supporting cast of semi regular Fincher faces and Chloe Sevingy are also well cast and yet again sadly their inclusion is understated. The story is a lot to chew on, so naturally the film hurtles at breakneck speed in order to get as much information crammed in as possible, this was Fincher perfecting his craft per say, his pacing has always been top notch, but here he fires scenes that are literally blink and you will miss some very important information. As mentioned earlier, hes still honing at this point and some of the character development with Paul Avery and some supporting actors kind of just doesnt happen. It's not critical as our focus fully shifts onto Jake and Mark for the final half but to continually refrence him once every 20 mins just feels slightly too tacked on for my liking. The film is gorgeous as per, however compared to the last outing, Fincher is more reserved, he uses his techniques to great effect, in order to gain a sense of dread and desperation. sparingly using tracking shots for when they really matter and it works. It's as if he just had to get all of that out his system and figure out what worked best for what. The grade on the film is also perfect, giving a real sense of time about it, each era is reconstructed brilliantly from colour schemes on set down to musical score, even the actors aging make up is brilliant. This film does however not lure you in, its a long film and unlike most of his other films, Fincher just presents his idea to you, if you like it you will invest and be truely horrified with its tales, however he doesnt try too hard to win everybody over. He isnt waiting for everyone to catch on and names and faces will come and go as quick as minutes before becoming a by product. This movie is strictly for Fincher fans and crime purists, anyone else will be left with a sense of boredom, confusion and most likely deflation by the end of the third act. A return to form and a stepping stone to greatness. under rated but far from perfect.

Cinema is greatly reflects this when films are released with the hook, "based on a true story." The range is broad when a hook like that is thrown, for what is true, what was made up, and what was left out. Where did this true story originate from (book, eyewitness account, memoir, rumor, etc.,) and was there anything learned from it? When a film is made from it, that is when a line is made from the s***y filmmakers to the brilliant ones. The one example I must point is David Fincher and his work in the Zodiac. Zodiac is based on the true story of the terror Zodiac unleashed with 5 (and possibly higher) murders and messages he sent to the media. What makes it fascinating or horrifying is the Zodiac Killer was never apprehended or identified even as today. People have become obsessive about the identity of the killer that it inspired books, movies, confessions, and hoax. Among these pieces, the most known is the non-fiction book Zodiac by Robert Graysmith which chronicles the events of the Zodiac from the widespread panic that was caused to obscurity. I have not read the book, but I assume Graysmith became obsessed with the subject so much that I thought of director David Fincher in his film the Zodiac. Zodiac is definitely an outstanding accomplishment from Fincher who directed The Game, Se7en, Fight Club, and Alien3. Zodiac is a lavish and authentic work with Fincher not only obsessed with telling the story, but the look and feel to it. It must have taken countless of hours and days and months to make the film while paying attention to the smallest detail. We get the looks, fashion, the music, the vehicles, and even the food when it comes to the Zodiac. The film centers around the story of the "Zodiac killer" and the investigation that followed by different branches of the police to a dedicated detective to even the cartoonist Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal). However, Graysmith is often overlooked when he expresses interest over the Zodiac. Yet, Graysmith manages to get a little help from crime reporter Paul Avery (Robert Downey Jr.) with note he has on the crime. Their newspaper, The Chronicle, then begins to receive letters from the killer taunting the police and promising to strike again. Fincher manages to reflect the tension and anxiety the city of San Francisco had. It is sometimes a little difficult to believe certain scenes happened which I would point out, but do not want to ruin it. However, it seems like Fincher has spent a great deal and focus on every scene even after film moves into the 90s. This is a definite works as a period piece even focusing on the toll it had on the characters. My favorite of all was Downey Jr. as Avery. He was pretty amusing as the film's antihero while Gyllenhaal displayed the flawed hero. He is dedicated to stopping the killer, but is oblivious to his personal life. Other performers to highlight are Mark Ruffalo, Brian Cox, Elias Koteas, and others.

Zodiac is, without doubt David Fincher's masterpiece and unbeknownst to everyone at the time, it will become the benchmark for all future Fincher films. It is the perfectly realised balance of a fine script, brilliant performances, technical acumen and above all an implacable restraint that is made all the more potent for the films one hundred and sixty-two minute length. All the problems with Se7en (still a great film) are obliterated in Zodiac, a far more difficult film to "enjoy" mostly because of the enormous cerebral pressure it places on the thinking viewer. The themes here are large: American obsession with serial killers, media interference in police procedure, pulp fictions obsession with true crime, the attention to detail of the obsessive, the reflexive nature of societies imaginations, the costs of obsession, the effects of time and memory on history, etc. If Fincher refused to turn the camera on his audience in Se7en, he does so with a cool calculated gaze in Zodiac, a film that rarely wavers into Fincher's characteristic flounces, such as helicopter shots or ambient police torch-light. Much of Fincher's integrity comes from a clear intention to tell the truth of the story, possibly because it is the first "true story" film Fincher will make, and his intention to avoid glamorizing the serial killer as he did in Se7en. By keeping so close to the facts of the story, by retaining a self consciousness about the end product, the meticulous perfectionism that characterises Fincher's directing style becomes the perfect vehicle for a long drawn out film about obsession on details.

Zodiac's opening scene is a fine example of the films merits. With Three Dog Night's lilting cover of 'Easy To Be Hard' wafting, the scene is of Vallejo, California on the fourth of July, fireworks bursting over the city. Darlene Ferrin (Ciara Hughes) is on her way to pick up Mike Mageau (Lee Norris), but the camera examines the houses celebrating fourth of July from her eye as she drives. When she drives Mike to a secluded lovers lane, another car approaches and although Mike wants to leave, Darlene claims everything is alright and doesn't make a move to drive away. Donovan's haunting 'Hurdy Gurdy Man' comes over the radio and increases as The Zodiac steps out of his car and shoots the pair. It's the scene that will become the defining murder leading to a suspect by Robert Greysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), the cartoonist at The San Francisco Chronicle who becomes obsessed with solving The Zodiac's puzzles and then the murder itself. Opening the film with the murder that causes the films denouement is not only clever writing, it also speaks to the fascination of the Zodiac obsessives. Fincher makes a film that the obsessives will love, even as he casts a shadow over the costs of that obsession. Greysmith, the writer of the two books the film is based on, is an obsessive, and James Vanderbuilt's decision to base the story on the fanboy who writes the books rather than the story of the killer is all the more powerful because it includes the detectives working the case as complicit in that obsession. If Greysmith becomes preoccupied because he loves puzzles and can't prevent himself from falling down the rabbit hole, then even more chilling is the fate of detective Dave Toshci (a soft-spoken Mark Ruffalo) who becomes haunted by association. Both men are reflected in characters who represent an alternate choice, Paul Avery (Robert Downey Junior) who sinks into depression and substance abuse against Greysmith's vigilance, and William Armstrong (Anthony Edwards) who voluntarily gives up detective work altogether because of the impact on his family against Toshci's being demoted and barred from the case for sending his own Zodiac letters. All four men will be ruined by their obsession with Armstrong as the only one who escapes. Fincher inserts wonderfully understated images to reflect this obsession, such as Greysmith, alone in his apartment filled with files about the Zodiac case after his family have left him, flicking through his newspaper clippings chillingly preserved in a family photo album.

Zodiac is the film where Fincher first gets his reputation for needing seventy takes on a set, and being so fastidiously precise that he gains support from the real life Toschi as well support from Vallejo police who hope the film will spark interest from the public. The film works within the obsession, becomes the obsession if you like, making itself another media representation of what it is seeking to expose. The Zodiac killer played with the media, using it to enhance his  notoriety. From the badges Paul Avery has made that everyone wears that say "I'm not Paul Avery" through the comment William Armstrong makes to David Toshci when Avery supposedly discovers the Zodiac's first victim, "It's very real. You know how I know? I saw it on TV," to the incredible collection images used in the montage of media lettering and zodiac puzzles sliding and moving over the top of the detectives trying to do their job.   This obsession with representation through the lens makes the Zodiac a different serial killer, a modern serial killer, and this becomes Fincher's second film that points to a problematic relationship with the camera. The Zodiac is never caught, which is interesting seeing as he calls famous people regularly, sent letters to the press, and forged personal relationships with the people obsessed with catching him. In Panic Room, David Fincher told us video surveillance becomes a self-cogitating nightmare, the lens always pointed back at us. In Zodiac he uses the media and film in the same way, revealing a relationship with technology that uses us more than we make a use of it.

It's easy to talk about Zodiac all day, but I wanted to make one additional mention of the incredible performances, which Fincher has claimed, came "from the fifty-fourth take." It is a film that uses detail almost like a character, but this extends to the performances, with everyone at the top of their game, making this Fincher film the best in his collection.

I'm convinced that David Fincher has chosen his filmmaking oeuvre as a way to disturb and test our senses. ZODIAC is certainly no exception but for the fact that it is based on a true, technically unsolved serial murder case that impacted an American nation for over a decade back in the sixties and seventies.  By setting its dark tone at the very start and building up to its frightening, inconclusive ending, Fincher manages to crawl his obsession with cruelty and madness under our skin.  It's a terrifying tale, told in a very simple step-by-step, matter-of-fact manner, painting an ugly portrait of life and then subjecting us to keep a mesmerized gaze at the screen only to realize we've been conned into watching a horrible reality steeped in a unending nightmare. The 2007 film Zodiac-about the infamous (and anonymous) hooded Zodiac serial killer who first emerged in the late 60s-is a hefty slow burn of a film about the process in bringing a mysterious murderer to justice. It is also a very dark and cynical look at the American Judicial System, where the misuse of media, coupled with mass hysteria and the lack of communication (or too much information) can lead to more harm than good. Being directed by David Fincher, his usual color palate perfectly exhibits the (lack of) hope of finding a faceless person with vague clues and intuitions into a bleak reality of false dawns and insensitive actualities. This isn't Dirty Harry-referenced in a very tongue in cheek way-were a Magnum can make a Perp squeal and confess. No, Zodiac depicts the arduous and time-consuming detective work where Due Process is the only lawful method of bringing people to justice. Showing such a time consuming process-a process that spans more than twenty years in the picture-has a fallout of the film being roughly 2  1/2 hours in length, but the viewing experience never "feels" long. The way Fincher glides from month to month (or year to year) is at first eye widening, then anxiousness creeps in, then it becomes darkly funny to finally wrap things up in a slightly underwhelming manner. Like Stanley Kubrick before him, Fincher isn't the most heartwarming filmmaker and he depicts things in a sterile, unflinching-or un-Finchering-way. Not to say the film is devoid of emotion as Jake Gyllenhaal and Mark Ruffalo both portray two tortured souls who commit their lives to finding out the true face behind the mask. Their descent into an endless abyss of circulated information is both cynically funny and depressing.  At the core of Zodiac is not a police procedural, nor is it a homicide mystery. Rather, it is a portrait of obsession and the lengths people will go to find solitude from their obsessions. It never really "builds" to anything in a traditional film watching sense, which may feel unsatisfactory. This lack of conformity leaves Zodiac sticking out like a partial fingerprint at a crime scene-there is a larger story behind it all-and Fincher patiently lets it all unwind in a grueling, timely, manner.

The best thing about "Zodiac" is how far away it goes from typical serial killer movie tendencies.  So many other films with a famed murderer as its subject tend to strive away from the real-life tragedies and make it one juicy filet of madness.  But "Zodiac" doesn't focus on the criminal behind the actions - it is instead like "All the President's Men", portraying a group of people who would not rest until the truth finally came to light.  
	Famously, the Zodiac was never identified, nor brought to justice, yet the film gives us closure that can't be felt through a Wikipedia page or a true crime novel.  It's a rather quiet, slow film, its 157 minutes just as long and frustrating as the investigation itself.
	The film opens with a murder, bizarre and bloody, and instantly we feel the same sort of eyes-agape anxiety the public felt during the time the Zodiac was at large.  The killer shoots them, a flashlight taped to his gun.  The victims are a clean-cut couple at a lover's lane, and only the man survives.  We already begin to lock these minute details into our brain to look for patterns, inevitably.  
	But Fincher isn't fixated on the killings, nor does he try to make them cinematic.  They are quick, horrifying, and almost awkward.  Real murder isn't artistic in the way the shower scene was in "Psycho", after all.  
	"Zodiac" is intent on solving the case, not dwelling on the carnage.  We are introduced to Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), a cartoonist, Paul Avery (Robert Downey Jr.), a reporter, and David Toschi (Mark Ruffalo), a detective.  The three are the most involved in the solving of the case, even if Avery eventually falls off the deep end.  Graysmith dedicates much of his life to it, which eventually disintegrates his marriage, while Toschi busies himself with other things, but can't help but still be curious about the murderer's identity.  
	There are so many false leads and dead ends that they are just as maddening to us as the people who actually lived it.  Sure, the Zodiac killer eventually stopped being  pressingly infamous, but the fact that we never find out who he is is like receiving an everlasting bug-bite that you can never scratch.
	The public is always fascinated with serial killers, transforming the gore into a paranoid thrill ride.  The backstories, the psychology, the mindset of the murderer can be an uncomfortably compelling thing.  Even I'm guilty of this.  But even with the most research, the most inside details, it's impossible to know the people that were touched by all the untamed danger. 
	The film spans over two-decades, and the beauty of it is that there are moments of terrifying intensity with others that are deadly boring.  But without boring bits, "Zodiac" wouldn't nearly be as good.  It's so true to life that those moments of nothingness make the film feel even more authentic.
	It's a long, imperfect ride, but "Zodiac" has a fantastic set of actors and a top-notch director on its side to make even the dullest of bits turn into something of interest.

How do you make a dramatic film about a real-life serial killer who was never caught? It's a pretty tall order, but I think they found the answer to the question with Zodiac. The first way they managed the seemingly impossible task was to avoid all the Hollywood tropes you find in serial killer films, in fact this one is so far removed from those cliches that it almost doesn't fit the genre. You see the focus is not really on the killer, we get a few brief scenes of his murders, but they take up a very small portion of the story. Instead this is about the people surrounding the case. It looks into the intricacies of police work, the time spent in the newspaper office dealing with the letters they received, and even the obsession of one lone man who "just has to know." There are loads of scenes that, in the hands of a lesser director, could easily have been boring or slowed the pace of the film. Yet David Fincher finds ways to make digging through paperwork, and questioning suspects seem exciting. Somehow, despite the fact that I knew the end result of the true story, they managed to keep me engaged and questioning whether they would be able to nail this next suspect.

I won't waste time talking about the acting performances, because they all were amazing. In fact I would say these are the finest performances I have ever seen from Jake Gyllenhaal, Mark Ruffalo, and Anthony Edwards. But every other performance was solid as well. The visual look of the film was also amazing. Just like playing intense music, the dark look to certain scenes added to the unsettling atmosphere. It felt like at any moment someone could get murdered or someone could be revealed as the killer. It was masterfully accomplished because I imagine that was exactly the feeling that people had back in those days. Yet Zodiac isn't all perfection. There are some moments in the movie that feel unnecessary for the main storyline. I know that the director and writer met with tons of people who were there at the time in order to find out how things actually happened, but as a result of this I think they included more minute details that were completely irrelevant to the story they were telling. This resulted in a longer run-time than I think the film warranted. My only other complaint is that, yes it's Hollywood cliche, but I want closure. I like that they held to the true story, but it's so unsatisfying walking away without the bad guy being caught. It's a minor complaint in what is otherwise an amazing film, which I highly recommend.
